title: Reading dvw files
text: The data project scouting software, data volley 4, files are the focus on this package. If your interested in some example files, you can find them here.

title: Reading dvw files
text: The data project scouting software, data volley 4, files are the focus on this package. If your interested in some example files, you can find them here.

title: Reading dvw files
text:
Reading a single dvw
The provided example file is used. You would typically fill in the None with the actual path of your dvw files.


Code
import pandas as pd
from datavolley import read_dv
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None) # Used so we can see the entire dataframe as it prints
pd.set_option('display.width', 300)
dv_instance = read_dv.DataVolley(None) # Replace `None` with path of your dvw file 
df = dv_instance.get_plays()
print(df[(df['skill'].notna()) & (df['skill'] != "Point")].head(10))

title: Reading dvw files
text:
Reading multiple dvw files
There are different methods when reading more than one dvw file. If you have more than 200 files you may consider using threading.
Here is one method to reading multiple files from a folder.


Code
import pandas as pd
from datavolley import read_dv
import os

# Assign path
dvw_path_folder = os.path.expanduser("~\\desktop\\dvws\\1")
file_extension = ".dvw"

# Get a list of all files with the specified extension in the directory
file_list = [f for f in os.listdir(dvw_path_folder) if f.endswith(file_extension)]

# Initialize an empty DataFrame to store combined data
combined_df = pd.DataFrame()

def process_file(path):
    dv_instance = read_dv.DataVolley(os.path.join(dvw_path_folder, path))
    df = dv_instance.get_plays()
    return df

# Loop through each file path
for file_name in file_list:
    combined_df = pd.concat([combined_df, process_file(file_name)], ignore_index=True)

print("DVW files read: " + str(len(combined_df['match_id'].unique())))

print(combined_df[(combined_df['skill'].notna()) & (combined_df['skill'] != "Point")].head(10))

title: Installing packages
text:
Using pip or rather package installer for Python, you can download pydatavolley.
Using windows:
pip install pydatavolley
If you are using a mac there are likely some additional steps you’ll need to follow to install pip first. You can find those here: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/how-to-install-pip-in-macos/#
Some additional packages used in this book:
pip install numpy
pip install pandas
pip install siuba
pip install pyjanitor

title: Installing packages
text:
Using pip or rather package installer for Python, you can download pydatavolley.
Using windows:
pip install pydatavolley
If you are using a mac there are likely some additional steps you’ll need to follow to install pip first. You can find those here: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/how-to-install-pip-in-macos/#
Some additional packages used in this book:
pip install numpy
pip install pandas
pip install siuba
pip install pyjanitor

title: Data cleaning
text: Depending on your needs, you may want to add a few items into your plays dataframe. Doing so can help navigate your data more efficiently in the long run.

title: Data cleaning
text:
If you see this data, there are a lot of empty columns. We can utilize pandas/siuba and pyjaniotr to help us remove empty columns and/or rows.

import pandas as pd
import requests
from datavolley import read_dv
from janitor import remove_empty
from siuba import _, filter, select
# Read in data
# Set the max rows and columns so we can see more data
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', 50)
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', 500)
pd.set_option('display.width', 400)
# Provided URL 
url = "https://mevza.volleynet.at/dl/L2RhdGF2b2xsZXkvMjAyMS9NRUxfbWVuLyZNSUwtMS5kdnc="

# Download the file
res = requests.get(url)
# Load the downloaded file
with open("example1.dvw", 'wb') as file:
    file.write(res.content)
dv_instance = read_dv.DataVolley("example1.dvw")
df = dv_instance.get_plays()

# filter out empty player_name
df1 = (df 
       >> filter((_.skill.notna()) & (_.skill != 'Point'))
      )
# And remove empty columns
df1 = remove_empty(df1)
print(df1)

title: Using python
text:
IDE or Integrated development environment. This book will be focused on use with Visual Studio Code (VSC).
However you can use R.

The methods are focused on using Windows VLC however, using a Mac will work just as well inasmuch as your installation of pip is properly performed.

title: Reading dvw files
section: Reading multiple dvw files from different folders
text:
Reading multiple dvw files from different folders
In the event you have dvw files inside multiple folders, you may consider the following method to parse those:


Code
import pandas as pd
from datavolley import read_dv
import os

# Assign path
dvw_path_folder = os.path.expanduser("~\\desktop\\dvws")
file_extension = ".dvw"

# Initialize an empty DataFrame to store combined data
combined_df = pd.DataFrame()

def process_file(path):
    dv_instance = read_dv.DataVolley(os.path.join(dvw_path_folder, path))
    df = dv_instance.get_plays()
    return df

# Loop through each file path in the directory and its subdirectories
for root, dirs, files in os.walk(dvw_path_folder):
    for file_name in files:
        if file_name.endswith(file_extension):
            file_path = os.path.join(root, file_name)
            combined_df = pd.concat([combined_df, process_file(file_path)], ignore_index=True)

print("DVW files read: " + str(len(combined_df['match_id'].unique())))

print(combined_df[(combined_df['skill'].notna()) & (combined_df['skill'] != "Point")].head(10))

title: Reading dvw files
section: Saving the dataframe as a csv
text:
Saving the dataframe as a csv
If you’d like to save your data into a csv.


Code
combined_df.to_csv('combined_data.csv') # Where your current directory lives


However, this method may present issues when it comes to encoding. You may want to choose some alternate methods when encoding becomes an issue. Saving to excel can help with that.


Code
# You may need to run pip install openpyxl before saving to excel
combined_df.to_excel('combined_data.xlsx')

title: Using python
text:
IDE or Integrated development environment. This book will be focused on use with Visual Studio Code (VSC).
However you can use R.

The methods are focused on using Windows VLC however, using a Mac will work just as well inasmuch as your installation of pip is properly performed.

title: Using python
section: VSC Enviorment vs Projects vs None
text:
VSC Enviorment vs Projects vs None
If you are a R user who doesn’t care so much about organizing project structure, using python can be similar but also messy in the long run. Simply create a file where your path currently is, read dvw file(s) from the desired path and away you go! Warning this can get messy and difficult to navigate if you start using multiple ad hoc files, reading hundreds of files, whilst running reports or dashboards.
The advantage of using environments is keeping your project structure easy to understand. You can also add your own package ingredients which can speed up the process of your file processing, keep clean your work space and run dashboards or reports easily.
Using projects is very simple in VSC, which can help ease the messiness if you intend on using more than just reading files. Simple create a folder in the directory you want, start VSC, and open folder! Your project is started and anything you save at that point will go to the folder which you created your new folder in. This also allows for different files to be imported into each other.

title: Using python
text:
Combing Python and R?
It is possible to use python in R studio, in this you can create a new project in R, parse your files in python and save a csv/excel file. Then read in R.

title: Getting started with pydatavolley
text:
Welcome to pydatavolley, where data analysis meets volleyball. This book is a curated collection of skills designed for the volleyball analyst eager to transcend the conventional boundaries of data exploration.
In the following chapters, we will delve into various topics that not only harness the power of Python but also explore the realm of R. Each chapter and section of this book is crafted to seamlessly integrate both languages, providing a comprehensive and versatile approach to data analysis in the context of volleyball. We will focus on using pandas, if your are a R user interesting in a more R tidyverse structure consider using siuba which replicates the use of dplyr from R’s tidyverse.
Whether you’re a seasoned analyst looking to enhance your skills or a newcomer eager to explore the intersection of data, pydatavolley is your guide.

title: Getting started with pydatavolley
text:
Welcome to pydatavolley, where data analysis meets volleyball. This book is a curated collection of skills designed for the volleyball analyst eager to transcend the conventional boundaries of data exploration.
In the following chapters, we will delve into various topics that not only harness the power of Python but also explore the realm of R. Each chapter and section of this book is crafted to seamlessly integrate both languages, providing a comprehensive and versatile approach to data analysis in the context of volleyball. We will focus on using pandas, if your are a R user interesting in a more R tidyverse structure consider using siuba which replicates the use of dplyr from R’s tidyverse.
Whether you’re a seasoned analyst looking to enhance your skills or a newcomer eager to explore the intersection of data, pydatavolley is your guide.

title: Getting started with pydatavolley
text:
Acknowledgements
Openvolley team and their support for my addition to pydatavolley.

title: Data cleaning
text: Depending on your needs, you may want to add a few items into your plays dataframe. Doing so can help navigate your data more efficiently in the long run.
